contextId.information: The "advice of the wicked" is spoken of as if it were a path to follow. AT: "who does not follow the advice of the wicked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who does not walk in the advice of the wicked

contextId.information: Surviving when God judges is spoken of as "standing." AT: "will not survive when God judges them" or "will be condemned when God judges them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]
contextId.quote: will not stand in the judgment

contextId.information: The people of other nations speak of Yahweh and the Messiah's rule over them as if it were shackles and chains.  AT: "We should free ourselves from their control; we should not let them rule over us any longer!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let us tear off the shackles ... throw off their chains

contextId.information: Defeating the nations is spoken of as breaking them, and his power is spoken of as an iron rod. AT: "You will defeat them completely by your power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will break them with an iron rod

contextId.information: A shield protects a soldier. David speaks as if God were a shield protecting him. AT: "you, Yahweh, protect me like a shield" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you, Yahweh, are a shield around me

contextId.information: Animals attack with their teeth. Breaking their teeth takes away their power to attack. David speaks as if Yahweh would come and physically fight against the wicked. AT: "you will make the wicked unable to harm me like someone breaking the teeth of a ferocious animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will break the teeth of the wicked

contextId.information: Peace is spoken of as if it were a place. AT: "I will be peaceful when I lie down and sleep" or "I will not be afraid of danger when I lie down and sleep"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: It is in peace that I will lie down and sleep

contextId.information: David speaks of righteousness as if it were a path and of teaching as leading. The phrase "your righteousness" means that God is righteous AT: "teach me to do what is righteous as you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lead me in your righteousness

contextId.information: Their throat is spoken of as if it were an open tomb, ready for dead bodies to put into it. Possible meanings are 1) "they say that they will kill people" or 2) "What they say kills people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their throat is an open tomb

contextId.information: God is spoken of as if he were a refuge, a place where people can be protected. AT: "May all those who go to you for protection rejoice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: may all those who take refuge in you rejoice

contextId.information: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to you for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take refuge in you

contextId.information: David speaks of the things that a wicked person does as if the person were pregnant and wickedness was the baby. AT:  "the wicked person. He makes plans to destroy people and produces harmful lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: one who is pregnant with wickedness ... conceives destructive plans ... gives birth to harmful lies

contextId.information: Causing babies to praise God is spoken of as if the praise were an object that God created in the babies' mouths and made come out. AT: "You have given babies and infants the ability to praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Out of the mouth of babies and infants you have created praise

contextId.information: Causing people to be forgotten is spoken of as blotting out their name.  AT: "you have caused them to be forgotten as if their name was blotted out" or "no one will ever remember them again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have blotted out their name forever and ever

contextId.information: Remembrance is spoken of as if it were a living being that could die. AT: "All remembrance of them has stopped" or "There is no longer any remembrance of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: All remembrance of them has perished

contextId.information: God is spoken of as if he were a place that people could go to for safety. AT: "Yahweh will also protect the oppressed" or "Yahweh will also provide safety for those who are oppressed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh also will be a stronghold for the oppressed

contextId.information: People dig pits in order to catch animals that fall into them. Here digging a pit represents making plans to destroy people. AT: "The nations are like people who dig a pit for others and then fall into it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The nations have sunk down into the pit that they made

contextId.information: Seeking God represents either 1) asking God for help or 2) thinking about God and obeying him. AT: "he does not ask God for help" or "he does not think about God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he does not seek God

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the wicked person catching people as if he were a hunter using a net to catch animals. AT: "He catches the oppressed like a hunter that catches an animal in a net and drags it away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He catches the oppressed when he pulls in his net

contextId.information: Refusing to pay attention to what people do is spoken of as forgetting. AT: "God does not pay attention" or "God does not care about what I do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God has forgotten

contextId.information: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to Yahweh for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take refuge in Yahweh

contextId.information: This describes those who desire to know God as if they were actually following him on a path. AT: "who desire to know him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who seek after him

contextId.information: This describes people who have rejected God as if they had stopped walking on the right path and had gone in another direction. AT: "They have all turned away from Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They have all turned away

contextId.information: Here "to be shaken" represents not living safely any longer. This can be stated in positive form. AT: "will live in safety" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: will never be shaken

contextId.information: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to you for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take refuge in you

contextId.information: Here David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a portion of land that has been given to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my chosen portion

contextId.information: God's blessings for David are spoken of as if they were a section of land that had been surveyed for him to possess. "Measuring lines" represents the surveyor's cords. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The place you have provided for me is pleasant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Measuring lines ... in pleasant places

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his obedience to God as if he were walking on a path. AT: "I am determined to follow your ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: my feet have not slipped

contextId.information: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to you for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take refuge in you

contextId.information: David speaks of God's protection as if he were a bird protecting its young under its wings. AT: "Keep me safe as a mother bird protects her babies by gathering them under her wing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hide me under the shadow of your wings

contextId.information: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a rock. The word "rock" is a picture of a safe place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh is my rock

contextId.information: Here the words "rock" and "fortress" share similar meanings and emphasize that Yahweh provides safety from enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my rock, my fortress

contextId.information: David speaks of death as if it were a person who could capture him and bind him with ropes. AT: "I was about to be killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The cords of death surrounded me

contextId.information: God's being angry is spoken of as if the there was a terrible earthquake. AT: "God was so angry that it was as if the earth ... shaken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Then the earth ... shaken because God was angry

contextId.information: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were breathing fire. This is a picture of how angry God was. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Smoke went up from out of his nostrils ... Coals were ignited by it

contextId.information: Here darkness is spoken of as if it were a tent. AT: "He made darkness a covering" or "He made darkness a hiding place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He made darkness a tent

contextId.information: Here the Psalmist speaks of the dangers of his enemies as if they were huge waves or forceful waters, from which Yahweh has rescued him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: surging water

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh's presence as if he were a light. These clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: For you give light to my lamp; Yahweh my God lights up my darkness

contextId.information: Here the writer speaks of God's protection as if it were a shield. The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated with the verb "save." AT: "your protection and saved me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the shield of your salvation

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the safety that God has provided as if it were a wide place for him to stand . AT: "a safe place for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: a wide place for my feet beneath me

contextId.information: Here the writer speaks of Yahweh's protection as if he were a rock that prevented his enemies from reaching him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:002|18:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my rock

contextId.information: Yahweh's protection of the writer is spoken of as if he lifted the writer up so high that his enemies could not reach him to harm him. AT: "you put me in a safe place high above" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you lifted me above

contextId.information: Here the writer speaks of the place that Yahweh created for the sun as if it were a tent. AT: "He created a place for the sun" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He has pitched a tent for the sun

contextId.information: Yahweh's decrees are spoken of as if they could be bought and tasted. AT: "If you could buy them, they would be of greater value than gold ... if you could taste them, they would be sweeter than honey" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They are of greater value than gold ... they are sweeter than honey

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God as if he were a rock that one could climb and be protected from his enemies. AT: "Yahweh, you are like my rock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh, my rock

contextId.information: God helping from his holy place is spoken of as if God were sending help. AT: "may Yahweh help you from his holy place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: send help from the holy place

contextId.information: Yahweh or the king destroying their enemies is spoken of as if their enemies are wood and Yahweh or the king will throw them into  furnace. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will burn them up as in a fiery furnace

contextId.information: The writer speaks of himself as if he were a worm. This emphasizes that he feels worthless or that the people treat him as if he were worthless. AT: "But it is like I am a worm and not a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am a worm and not a man

contextId.information: The writer speaks about "trouble" as if it were an object that is near him. AT: "for my enemies are near me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for trouble is near

contextId.information: Possible meanings for "dust of death" are 1) it refers to a person turning to dust after they die. AT: "You are about to let me die and become dust" or 2) it is a way of speaking about the grave, which would mean God is causing the writer to die. AT: "You have laid me in my grave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have laid me in the dust of death

contextId.information: The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were dogs. His enemies are coming close to him like wild dogs do to a dying animal. AT: "my enemies are like dogs that have surrounded me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: dogs have surrounded me

contextId.information: This continues the dog metaphor. The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were dogs that are biting and piercing his hands and feet with their teeth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they have pierced my hands and my feet

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the writer is so thin that he can see his bones. AT: "I can see all of my bones" or "I can feel each of my bones" or 2) this continues the dog metaphor and the writer can see his bones after the dogs have ripped his flesh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I can count all my bones

contextId.information: Starting to obey Yahweh is spoken of as if the people physically turn toward Yahweh. AT: "will remember Yahweh and obey him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will remember and turn to Yahweh

contextId.information: The writer speaks about Yahweh as if he were a shepherd. This emphasizes how God cares for people as a shepherd cares for his sheep. AT: "Yahweh is like a shepherd to me" or "Yahweh cares for me as a shepherd cares for his sheep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh is my shepherd

contextId.information: The writer speaks about himself as if he were a sheep, and he speaks about Yahweh as if he were a shepherd. AT: He gives me rest like a shepherd who leads his sheep to lie down in green pastures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He makes me to lie down in green pastures

contextId.information: The writer describes a person experiencing terrible trouble as if he were a sheep walking through a dark and dangerous valley. There a sheep could get lost or attacked by a wild animal. AT: "Though my life is like walking through a dark and dangerous valley" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Even though I walk through a valley of darkest shadow

contextId.information: Yahweh being good and faithful to a person is spoken of as if goodness and covenant faithfulness are things that pursue after a person. AT: "Surely you will be good and faithful to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Surely goodness and covenant faithfulness will pursue me

contextId.information: The phrase "lift up my life" is a metaphor. Possible meanings are 1) the writer is giving himself to Yahweh, which means he is completely depending on Yahweh. AT: "I give myself to you" (UDB) or 2) he is offering prayer and adoration to Yahweh. AT: "I worship and adore you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I lift up my life

contextId.information: Yahweh paying attention to a person and considering him is spoken of as if Yahweh were physically turning towards the person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Turn toward me

contextId.information: The word "walked" is a metaphor for behavior. AT: "I have behaved" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have walked

contextId.information: "Sweep away" is a metaphor for destruction. AT: "Do not destroy me along with sinners" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not sweep me away with sinners

contextId.information: "Walk" is a metaphor for behavior. AT: "I will behave with integrity"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will walk in integrity

contextId.information: Possible meanings are that "level ground" represents 1) a safe place or 2) right behavior (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: level ground

contextId.information: Destroying someone completely is spoken of as if it were devouring a person's flesh. He did not mean that they wanted to eat his body. AT: "to destroy me"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to devour my flesh

contextId.information: A person really wanting something and continually asking God for it is spoken of as if he were seeking to find something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will seek that

contextId.information: God keeping the writer safe from his enemies is spoken of as if God were placing him on a high rock where his enemies cannot reach him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will lift me high on a rock

contextId.information: How a person should behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path that person should travel. AT: "Teach me how you want me to live" or "Teach me to do what you want me to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Teach me your way

contextId.information: Here violence is spoken for as if it was something a person could breathe out. AT: "they say that they will do violent things to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they breathe out violence

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for strength. AT: "my strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my rock

contextId.information: God punishing people is spoken of as if he physically drags them away. In this metaphor Yahweh may be dragging them to prison, exile, or death. AT: "Do not remove me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not drag me away

contextId.information: This represents Yahweh's protecting the writer. AT: "he protects me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my shield

contextId.information: This speaks about the people of God as if they were something God inherited. AT: "your possession" or "those who belong to you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your inheritance

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God rescuing him and keeping him from dying as if God had drawn him up from a deep well. AT: "you rescued me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have raised me up

contextId.information: The phrase "sought favor" means to ask for help. AT: "I pleaded for you to help me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sought favor from my Lord

contextId.information: The writer speaks of gladness as if it were a garment that he could put on. AT: "caused me to be glad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: clothed me with gladness

contextId.information: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "I go to you, Yahweh, for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In you, Yahweh, I take refuge

contextId.information: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were a strong fortress in which the writer would be protected from his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a stronghold to save me

contextId.information: Yahweh is spoke of as if he were a huge rock that would protect the writer from attack. AT: "like a huge rock on which I can be safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my rock

contextId.information: The writer is spoken of as if he were a bird caught in a hidden net, and waiting for Yahweh to free him from the trap. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Pluck me out of the net that they have hidden for me

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards him as if Yahweh's face shone a light on him. AT: "Act favorably towards your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Make your face shine on your servant

contextId.information: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:031:001|31:1]]. AT: "those who go to you for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take refuge in you

contextId.information: Yahweh's presence is spoken of as if it is a strong building where the writer would be safe. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In the shelter

contextId.information: Yahweh is spoken of as if he was a safe place from the attacks of the writer's enemies. AT: "You are like a place where I can hide myself from my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You are my hiding place

contextId.information: Living in the correct way is spoken of as if it were a path that the writer should walk. AT: "how you should live your life"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the way which you should go

contextId.information: Here "upright" is used as a metaphor for something that is true. AT: "Yahweh always does what he says that he will do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh's word is upright

contextId.information: Here "sought Yahweh" means David was asking Yahweh for help. AT: "I prayed to Yahweh" (UDB) or "I asked Yahweh for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I sought Yahweh

contextId.information: The angel of Yahweh is spoken of as if he were an army that camps around someone in order to protect them. AT: "guards" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: camps around

contextId.information: Here "Turn away" is a metaphor for avoiding evil. AT: "Refuse to do evil" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Turn away from evil

contextId.information: These phrases describe God as a warrior who is preparing himself for battle. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Grab your small shield and large shield ... your spear and battle ax

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) these enemies are literally chasing the writer or 2) this is a metaphor for people who are enemies of the writer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those who chase me

contextId.information: Here "seek my life" means they desire to kill the writer. AT: "who are trying to kill me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who seek my life

contextId.information: This refers to a way that is hidden and dangerous. AT: "hidden and full of dangers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: dark and slippery

contextId.information: The schemes of the wicked are spoken of as if they were a net that they set to catch the writer. AT: "they want to catch me in a net like a small animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they set their net for me

contextId.information: This is the same metaphor as in verse 7. The net is intended to catch the writer. AT: "Let them fall into the pit that they dug for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Let them fall into it

contextId.information: This is a metaphor which means they give back evil in exchange for the good they have received.  AT: "In return for my doing good things for them, they do evil things to me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They repay me evil for good

contextId.information: Here the writer speaks of his enemies as if they were vicious lions. AT: "from my enemies who attack me like wild animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from the lions

contextId.information: This does not mean that God is actually asleep. The writer wants God to intervene. Both words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the urgency of this request. AT: "I feel like you are sleeping! Wake up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: Arouse yourself and awake

contextId.information: The greatness of God's covenant faithfulness is spoken of as if it was very high. AT: "is as high as the heavens" or "is enormously great" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: reaches to the heavens

contextId.information: God's covenant faithfulness is spoken of as if it were rare and expensive jewels. AT: "Your covenant faithfulness is as valuable as rare jewels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: How precious is your covenant faithfulness

contextId.information: This does not mean that God has a house with food. This is a metaphor for abundant provision. AT: "as if they were eating the rich food from your house" or "with your rich blessings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with the richness of the food of your house

contextId.information: The destruction of the wicked is spoken of as if they were a branch of a plant that was cut off and thrown away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will be cut off

contextId.information: The possession of the land is spoken of as if it will be received as an inheritance. AT: "will receive the land as their own possession" or "will live safely in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will inherit the land

contextId.information: The possession of the land is spoken of as if it will be received as an inheritance. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:037:008|37:9]]. AT: "will receive the land as their own possession" or "will live safely in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will inherit the land

contextId.information: The possession of the land is spoken of as if it had been received as an inheritance. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:037:008|37:9]]. AT: "will receive the land as their own possession" or "will be allowed to live safely in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will inherit the land

contextId.information: The destruction of the wicked is spoken of as if they were a branch of plant that was cut off and thrown away. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:037:008|37:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will be cut off

contextId.information: Here "stumble" and "fall" refer to the man's reaction to difficult times. AT: "Though he has difficult times, he will not utterly fail" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Though he stumbles, he will not fall down

contextId.information: To stop doing something is spoken of as if the person turned away from it. AT: "Stop doing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Turn away from

contextId.information: The destruction of the wicked is spoken of as if they were a branch of plant that was cut off and thrown away. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:037:008|37:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will be cut off

contextId.information: The possession of the land is spoken of as if it had been received as an inheritance. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:037:008|37:9]]. AT: "will receive the land as their own possession" or "will be allowed to live safely in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will inherit the land

contextId.information: The destruction of the wicked is spoken of as if they were a branch of a plant that was cut off and thrown away. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:037:008|37:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: are cut off

contextId.information: The severity of Yahweh's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if Yahweh had shot arrows into the writer. AT: "Your punishment is as painful as if you had shot arrows into me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your arrows pierce me

contextId.information: The writer's is so sick with fever that it is as if he is burning inside. AT: "My body is burning with fever" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am filled with burning

contextId.information: The writer's illness is so severe that it is as if a huge weight is pressing down on him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: utterly crushed

contextId.information: The plots of the writer's enemies are spoken of as if they were traps that they had set to catch him like an animal. AT: "set traps to catch me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lay snares for me

contextId.information: Possible meanings for this metaphor are 1) "I am so sick that I am about to die" or 2) "I will soon be ruined." It may be best not to interpret the metaphor in the text. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am about to stumble

contextId.information: The actions of the writer's enemies are spoken of as a financial transaction where they gave him evil things in exchange for good things. The abstract nouns "evil" and "good" can be stated as actions. AT: They give me bad actions in exchange for my good actions for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: They repay me evil for good

contextId.information: To "muzzle" means to keep a mouth shut. Here David means that he will not speak while he is with an evil person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: muzzle

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his lifespan is if it could be measured by the width of his hand. AT: "only a very short time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: only the width of my hand

contextId.information: Here troubles are spoken of as if they were objects that surround and trap the speaker. AT: "there are more troubles around me than I can count" or "more troubles come to me than I can count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Troubles that cannot be numbered surround me

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God's deliverance as if it were a light that shows him the way and truth that teaches him how to live. AT: "guide me with your light and truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: send out your light and your truth

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his enemies' defeat as if they are "down" and of their preparing to fight as if they are "up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: push down ... tread them under ... rise up

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God's rejection of Israel as if he were discarding an unwanted piece of clothing. AT: "rejected us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: thrown us off

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh allowing Israel's enemies to conquer them as if he were selling the people of Israel to their enemies but does not require any payment from their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sell your people for nothing

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his dishonor as if it were an object that is always in front of him for him to see. The phrase means that he is always thinking about his dishonor. AT: "I think about my dishonor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my dishonor is before me

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God's punishment as if it were breaking a fragile object. AT: "you have punished us severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have severely broken us

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his heart as if it were a container that overflows with liquid. The word "heart" represents his emotions, which are excited by the song that he sings. AT: "My emotions are excited about a good subject" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My heart overflows on a good subject

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his tongue as if it were a pen. He speaks words as skillfully as an experienced writer writes words. AT: "my tongue is like the pen of person who writes well" or "I speak words as skillfully as an experienced writer can write words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my tongue is the pen of a ready writer

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the people who live in Tyre as if they are Tyre's children. AT: "The people of Tyre" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The daughter of Tyre

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God as if he were a place where people can go for safety. AT: "God gives us safety and strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God is our refuge and strength

contextId.information: Here, the word "moved" is the same word translated as "shaken" in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:046:001|v. 2]]. The writer speaks of the destruction of Jerusalem by armies as if an earthquake were to destroy it. This can be stated in active form. AT: "nothing will be able destroy her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: she will not be moved

contextId.information: Here, the word "raged" is the same word that the writer used in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:046:001|v. 3]] to describe the waters of the sea. The writer speaks of the fear of the nations as if it was the violent movements of the sea during a strong storm. AT: "The nations are terrified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The nations raged

contextId.information: Here, the word "shaken" is the same word that the writer used in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:046:001|v. 2]] to describe the effect of an earthquake on the mountains. The writer speaks of the overthrow of kingdoms by armies as if an earthquake were to destroy them. This can be stated in active form. AT: "armies overthrew the kingdoms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the kingdoms were shaken

contextId.information: The writer speaks of conquering other nations as if it were putting those nations underneath their feet. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: under us ... under our feet

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the land of Israel as if it were an inheritance that God has given the people as a permanent possession. AT: "He chooses this land as an inheritance for us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He chooses our inheritance for us

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God's conquering the nations as if God were a king ascending his throne, which was located in the temple. AT: "God has gone up into the temple as people shouted" (UDB) or "God has ascended to his throne as people shouted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: God has gone up with a shout

contextId.information: Possible meanings are that "shields" 1) refers to instruments of war. AT: "God has more power than the weapons of all the kings on the earth" (UDB) or 2) refers to the rulers of the nations who are spoken of as shields who protect their nations. AT: "the kings of the earth are subject to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the shields of the earth belong to God

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God as if he were a place where people can go for safety. AT: "God has made himself known as one who gives safety to the people in Mount Zion's palaces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God has made himself known in her palaces as a refuge

contextId.information: The writer speaks of righteousness as if it were an object that God could hold in his hand. Here the word "hand" refers to God's power and authority to rule. AT: "you rule with righteousness" or "you are righteous as you rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: your right hand is full of righteousness

contextId.information: The writer speaks of people who are weak or insignificant in society as being low and of people who are important and powerful as being high. Together, the words "low" and "high" represent all people. AT: "both important people and unimportant people" (UDB) or "people of every social class" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: both low and high

contextId.information: The writer speaks of experiencing something as if it were seeing that thing. AT: "he will die and his body will decay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will see decay

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the fate of fools as if it is the destination at the end of the path on which they walk. AT: "This is the fate of those who practice folly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This, their way, is their folly

contextId.information: Being acceptable to God is spoken of as being clean. God makes people acceptable by forgiving their sins.  AT:  "Wash away all my sin" or "Forgive all my sins so that I will be acceptable to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity

contextId.information: Being acceptable to God is spoken of as being clean or white. God makes people acceptable by forgiving their sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Purify me ... I will be clean ... wash me ... I will be whiter than snow

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God as if God were a priest who would sprinkle water on him to make him  acceptable to God. AT: "Make me acceptable by sprinkling water on me with hyssop" or "Forgive me for my sins so that I will be acceptable to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Purify me with hyssop

contextId.information: Thinking about someone's sins is spoken of as seeing them. Forgiving or refusing to think about the sins is spoken of as choosing not to see them. AT: "Do not look at my sins" or "Do not remember my sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Hide your face from my sins

contextId.information: A broken spirit represents a humble attitude. AT: "humility" or "a person who becomes humble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: a broken spirit

contextId.information: Here words that harm others are spoken of as if they were animals that devour people. AT: "words that  harm others" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: words that devour others

contextId.information: Being alive on earth is spoken of as if people are plants with roots in the ground. God killing someone is spoken of as digging up the plant's roots and taking it out of the ground. AT: "he will take you out the land of the living" or "He will kill you so that you will no longer be on earth with living people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: root you out of the land of the living

contextId.information: Seeking God as a person would look for someone is spoken of as "seeking" God. Possible meanings are 1) wanting to know God. AT: "who want to know him" or 2) worshiping God. AT: "who worship him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who seek after him

contextId.information: Punishment is spoken as if it were payment. AT: "He will do the evil to my enemies that they have done to me" or "He will cause the evil that my enemies have done to me to be done to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will repay my enemies with evil

contextId.information: Causing trouble is spoken of as bringing trouble. AT: "they cause me to have great troubles" or "they do wicked things to me and so I suffer"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they bring trouble on me

contextId.information: Becoming fearful and trembling is spoken of as if fearfulness and trembling are things that come on a person. AT: "I have become very fearful and I tremble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Fearfulness and trembling have come on me

contextId.information: Destroying something is spoken of as eating all of it. Possible meanings are "Destroy my enemies'  plans" or "Destroy my enemies." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Devour them

contextId.information: Here troubles are spoken of as if they were burdens that people have to carry. Trusting God to help us when we have troubles is spoken of as putting our burdens on him so that he can carry them for us. AT: "Give Yahweh your problems" or "Trust God to help you with all your troubles like someone who trusts a stronger person to carry his load" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Place your burdens on Yahweh

contextId.information: The enemies' fierce attack is spoken of as if they were crushing his body by marching on it. AT: "My enemies attack me severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My enemies trample me

contextId.information: Repeating what someone says but changing it a little so that it means something different is spoken of as twisting their words. AT: "they  say that I said things than I did not say" or "they claim that I said things, but they lie" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they twist my words

contextId.information: God's concern for the psalmist is spoken of as if God counted each time that the psalmist has walked in sadness and with no place to go for comfort. AT: "You care about all the times that I have been wandering alone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You number my wanderings

contextId.information: God's concern for the psalmist is spoken of as if he wrote the number of the psalmist's tears in his book. This question is used to remind God about how greatly he cares for the psalmist. AT: "you have written about them in your book" or "you remember my cries" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: are they not in your book?

contextId.information: Being obligated to do something is spoken of as if the duty to do something is on a person. AT: "I must fulfill my vows to you" or "I must do what I promised you I would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The duty to fulfill my vows to you is on me

contextId.information: Living and being seen by God is spoken of as walking before God. AT: "so that I may live in God's presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that I may walk before God

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of God as if he were a mother bird that protects its babies by huddling them under its wings. AT: "I trust you to protect me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I stay under your wings for protection

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of Saul's desire to kill him as if Saul sought to destroy an  enemy. AT: "until this trouble is finished" or "until I am no longer in danger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: until this destruction is over

contextId.information: God's being kind and faithful is spoken of as if he were sending his kindness and faithful. AT: "God will be kind to me and trustworthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God will send me his loving kindness and his faithfulness

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of his enemies as if they were lions. AT: "I live among fierce enemies" or "Fierce enemies surround me like lions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My life is among lions

contextId.information: The tongue represents what someone says, and the enemies' cruel words are spoken of as if they were swords. AT: "whose cruel words are like sharp swords" or "who cause terrible trouble for me by what they say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whose tongues are sharp swords

contextId.information: His enemies' plans to capture him are spoken of as if they had spread out a net on the ground to trap him. AT: "It is as though my enemies have spread a net out to trap me" or "They planned to capture me like people who spread out a net to trap an animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They spread out a net for my feet

contextId.information: The harm that came to his enemies when they tried to capture him is spoken of as if they fell into the trap that they had made for him.  AT: "They themselves fell into the pit they had dug for me" or "But they themselves were hurt by what they planned to do to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They themselves have fallen into the middle of it

contextId.information: The wicked are spoken of as if they were thornbush branches, and God's swift punishment of them is spoken of as if he were to quickly blow them away or sweep them away. AT: "God will destroy wicked people faster than a whirlwind can blow away thornbush branches that have been put under a cooking pot and lit with fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Before your pots can feel the thorn's burning heat ... the green thorns and the burning thorns alike

contextId.information: Saying terrible things is spoken of as belching. These terrible things may have been insults or threats. AT: "they say terrible things" or "they shout out terrible words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they belch out with their mouths

contextId.information: Destroying them completely is spoken of either as burning them up or eating them. AT: "Be angry with them and destroy them completely so there will be no more of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Consume them in wrath, consume them so that they will be no more

contextId.information: God's rejecting people is spoken of as if he had thrown them away. AT: "you have rejected us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have cast us off

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of the disaster in his country as if it were an earthquake. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have made the land tremble; you have torn it apart

contextId.information: God chose men from the tribe of Judah to be the kings of his people, and he speaks of that tribe as if it were his scepter.  AT: "the tribe of Judah is like my scepter" or "Judah is the tribe through whom I rule my people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Judah is my scepter

contextId.information: God speaks of Moab being unimportant as if Moab were a washbasin or a lowly servant. AT: "Moab is like a bowl that I use for washing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Moab is my washbasin

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God's ability to protect him as if God were a rock. AT: "He is the only one who can protect and rescue me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He alone is my rock and my salvation

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God's punishment of the evildoers as if God were shooting arrows at them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But God will shoot them ... with his arrows

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God's causing the evildoers' plans to fail as if God were making them stumble in their paths. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will make them stumble" or "God will cause their plans to fail" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: They will be made to stumble

contextId.information: God beginning to act is spoke of as if he stands up. AT: "Let God begin to act" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let God arise

contextId.information: God's enemies are spoken of as if they are smoke that is easily blown away by the wind. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Drive them away as the wind blows away smoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: As smoke is driven away, so drive them away

contextId.information: God is spoken of as a compassionate God who acts like a father to orphans. AT: "One who acts like a father to children who have no parents" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A father of the fatherless

contextId.information: God is spoken of as if he places lonely people into families. "God provides families for those who have no one to live with" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God puts the lonely into families

contextId.information: The rebukes of the writer's enemies are spoken of as if they are a heavy load that he has had to carry. AT: "I have endured the insults of my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have borne rebuke

contextId.information: The writer speaks of himself as if he were not part of his own family. AT: "My brothers no longer know or accept me at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have become a stranger to my brothers

contextId.information: The writer speaks of his danger from his enemies as if he was sinking into a pit of mud. "Do not allow me to sink anymore in the mud" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Pull me out of the mire, and do not let me sink

contextId.information: Here the "pit" is spoken of as if it has a mouth like a person and could eat the writer. AT: "Do not let the pit consume me" or "Do not let the pit of death close over me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not let the pit shut its mouth on me

contextId.information: The writer asks God to redeem him as if the writer were a slave whose freedom God could purchase. AT: "free me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: redeem me

contextId.information: The writer would like for his enemies' food to completely ruin them as if they were small animals caught in a snare or a trap. AT: "May their food ruin them like a snare ... may it destroy them like a trap" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let their table before them become a snare ... let it become a trap

contextId.information: The writer speaks of eyes that cannot see well as if they were darkened. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Please make them unable to see anything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Let their eyes be darkened

contextId.information: God's demonstration of his anger is described as if he poured it out on his enemies like water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Pour out your indignation on them

contextId.information: To be stopped or thwarted is spoken of as being turned back from their attack. AT: "stopped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turned back

contextId.information: Seeking God represents either 1) asking God for help or 2) thinking about God and obeying him. AT: "ask you for help" or "think about you and obey you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: seek you

contextId.information: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to you, Yahweh, for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In you, Yahweh, I take refuge

contextId.information: The psalmist believes that Yahweh will protect him and make him as safe as if he were hiding on top of a large mountain or inside a man-made fortress. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you are my rock and my fortress

contextId.information: "Do not force me to go away from you." For God to reject him is spoken of as God forcing him to go away. AT: "do not reject me" (UDB) See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:051:010|51:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not throw me away

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of the good things God has done as though they were put together as a high building or a mountain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your righteousness also, God, is very high

contextId.information: "The depths of the earth" is a metaphor for where people go when they die. The psalmist had not already died, but he speaks as if he had. AT: "when we are near death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: from the depths of the earth

contextId.information: "destroy completely the one who oppresses them"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: break in pieces the oppressor

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "We do not see any more miraculous signs from God" or 2) "All our sacred symbols are gone" or 3) if speaking of the flags and symbols of an army, "Our army has been completely destroyed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: We do not see any more signs

contextId.information: Leviathan is a sea monster. It represents a cruel enemy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: leviathan

contextId.information: Asaph speaks of insulting words as if they were physical objects, like stones, which the enemy was throwing at Yahweh. AT: "the enemy insulted you many times" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the enemy hurled insults at you

contextId.information: This phrase may be a metaphor for the enemies of Israel. AT: "a savage enemy that is like a wild animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a wild animal

contextId.information: The foam is a metaphor for the power of the wine to make people drunk, AT: "strong wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: foaming wine

contextId.information: The horns of an animal are a metaphor for the power of a person. AT: "take away all power from" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cut off all the horns of

contextId.information: "He caused meat to fall from the sky like rain, and there was so much of it that it covered the ground like dust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He rained down meat on them like dust

contextId.information: The writer speaks about God as if he were a hill or mountain where people could go to be safe from their enemies. AT: "God was the one who protected them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God was their rock

contextId.information: Asaph speaks of God's anger as if it were an angry person whom God held onto to keep him from attacking the one who had made him angry. AT: "did not punish them even though he was angry with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: held back his anger

contextId.information: The flies made the Egyptians as almost as unhappy as they would have if they had eaten the Egyptians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: that devoured them

contextId.information: Asaph speaks of the crops as a gift that God gave to the grasshoppers. AT: "He allowed the grasshopper to eat their crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He gave their crops to the grasshopper

contextId.information: Asaph speaks of God's people as if they were a small object God would give as a gift, and of the sword, a metonym for death in war, as if it were a person who could receive a gift. AT: "He allowed people to kill all his people in war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He handed his people over to the sword

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "The enemy used fire to kill all their young men" or 2) "Their young men died quickly in battle like a fire burns dry grass." Do not communicate that these people used guns. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Fire devoured their young men

contextId.information: "it was as if the Lord awoke from sleeping" (see UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Lord awakened as one from sleep

contextId.information: Asaph speaks of the evil deeds that the neighboring countries did against Israel as "insults," and as if they were physical items. He asks the Lord to count those deeds, and for every one that the neighboring countries committed, he asks the Lord to have someone do seven evil deeds to the neighboring countries. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Pay back ... the insults ... Lord

contextId.information: onto their knees and thighs as they are sitting. This is a metaphor for "directly and personally." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: into the laps

contextId.information: Asaph is referring to God as the one who leads and protects Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Shepherd of Israel

contextId.information: Asaph compares the nation of Israel to a vine made ready to transplant. AT: "You brought us, like a vine, out of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: You brought a vine out of Egypt

contextId.information: "You cleared the land for the vine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You cleared the land for it

contextId.information: God taking care of all the needs of the people is spoken of as if he were a mother bird feeding her baby birds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it

contextId.information: God allowing the people to remain stubborn is spoken of as if God were giving them over to an enemy to let the enemy harm them. AT: "Therefore, I let them be stubborn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So I gave them over to their own stubborn way

contextId.information: God causing the best wheat to grow in Israel is spoken of as if he would literally feed the wheat to the people. AT: "I would allow the Israelites to eat the finest wheat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I would feed Israel with the finest wheat

contextId.information: The gods corrupting the moral order that Yahweh established is spoken of as if the gods were shaking the earth and making it fall apart. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all the foundations of the earth crumble

contextId.information: God is spoken of as if strength was actually found in him. AT: "whom you strengthen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whose strength is in you

contextId.information: Yahweh who guides and protects his people is spoken of as if he were the sun and a shield. AT: "For Yahweh God guides us like the light from the sun, and he protects us like a shield" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For Yahweh God is our sun and shield

contextId.information: God no longer punishing the Israelites is spoken of as if wrath were an object that Yahweh could take away from the Israelites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have withdrawn all your wrath

contextId.information: A person changing the way he behaves is spoken of as if he were physically turning to a different direction. AT: "Yet they must not start doing foolish things again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yet they must not turn again to foolish ways

contextId.information: "This one" refers to the people from the nations that the writer mentions. Although they were not physically born in Zion, those who follow God are natives of Jerusalem spiritually. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This one was born there

contextId.information: Yahweh acknowledging that the people from other nations belong to him is spoken of as if he were a king writing down the names of the people who live in his city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh writes in the census book of the nations

contextId.information: The writer speaks of himself as if he were a container and troubles are the contents that fill the container. AT: "For I am very troubled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For I am filled with troubles

contextId.information: People treating the writer as if he were already dead is spoken of as if he were a corpse that they left unburied. AT: I am left alone as if I were dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am abandoned among the dead

contextId.information: God no longer using his power to help dead people is spoken of as if God literally cut him off or removed him from his power. AT: "you no longer use your power to help them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they are cut off from your power

contextId.information: This speaks about God being very angry with the writer as if God's wrath were a heavy object lying on top of the writer. AT: "I feel your great anger" or "I feel how very angry you are with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your wrath lies heavy on me

contextId.information: The writer's physical condition that makes him repulsive to his friends is spoken of as if he were in closed into a confining space. AT: "It is as though I were in a prison" (UDB) or "I am trapped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am hemmed in

contextId.information: This speaks of God punishing the writer as if God's actions are a large wave rising out of the sea that fall on and crush the writer. AT: "It is as if your angry actions crush me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your angry actions have passed over me

contextId.information: God always doing what he promised to do is spoken of as if his faithfulness were a building that God has built and made firm. This can be stated in active form. AT: "You will always be faithful because of your covenant with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Covenant faithfulness has been established forever

contextId.information: Yahweh always causing one of David's descendants to be king is spoken of as if David's descendants are a building that Yahweh will build and make firm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will establish your descendants forever

contextId.information: Yahweh always dong what he promises to do is spoken of as if his truthfulness were a cloak or garment that wraps around him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your truthfulness surrounds you

contextId.information: God ruling as king and doing what is right and just is spoken of as if God's throne were a building, and righteousness and justice were its foundation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Righteousness and justice are the foundation of your throne

contextId.information: The king who protects his people and whom Yahweh chose is spoken of as if he were a shield that belongs to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For our shield belongs to Yahweh

contextId.information: God always being loyal and doing what he promises for David is spoken of as if truth and faithfulness were objects that would be with David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My truth and my covenant faithfulness will be with him

contextId.information: Yahweh giving David special rank and privileges over all other people is spoken of as if David would be Yahweh's firstborn son. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I also will place him as my firstborn son

contextId.information: The enemies shouting insults at the king is spoken of as if insults were an object that the enemies throw violently at the king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your enemies hurl insults

contextId.information: Because "live" and "stay" mean almost the same thing, as do "shelter" and "shadow," which are both metaphors for protection, you may need to combine the two lines into one. AT: "The Most High, the Almighty, will care for all those who live where he can protect them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: He who lives  ... will stay ... of the Almighty

contextId.information: A "refuge" is any place a person can go and have someone or something protect him. A "fortress" is something that people make so they can protect themselves and their property. Asaph uses them here as metaphors for protection. AT: "the one to whom I can go and he will protect me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my refuge and my fortress

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of life as if it were something someone could eat. AT: "I will allow him to live a long and happy life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will satisfy him with long life

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of righteous people as if they were trees that produce food. AT: "They please God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They bear fruit

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of where God lives as if it were high above the earth. AT: "in heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: on high

contextId.information: The psalmist writes of the the wicked speaking as if their words were a liquid being poured out. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They pour out their arrogant words

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of powerful people treating powerless people badly as if it were crushing them or breaking them in pieces. AT: "They completely destroy" or "They greatly harm." See how "break in pieces" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:072:004|72:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They crush

contextId.information: Here "tower" is a metaphor for protection. AT: "Yahweh has protected me from my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh has been my high tower

contextId.information: These two phrases are both metaphors for the people seeing how much evil they could do before Yahweh would punish them. The phrases say basically the same thing and can be combined. AT: "tested me" or "wanted to see if they could do evil things without my punishing them ... tested whether I would continue to be patient with them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: tested me ... tried me

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks as if those who were strong enough to rule were the physically higher than others. AT: "rule over all the people who live on" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: are most high above all

contextId.information: God's people are like his sheep. AT: "the people God provides for and protects" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the sheep of his pasture

contextId.information: Here David speaks about "living" as if it were "walking." AT: "I will live in a way that is honest and right" or "I will live a life full of integrity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will walk in the way of integrity

contextId.information: Here David speaks about "living" as if it were walking." Also, David speaks of overseeing his house with integrity, as if integrity were a physical object residing in his house. AT: "I will oversee my house with integrity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will walk with integrity within my house

contextId.information: David describes God causing him to become weak as if his strength were a physical item that could be taken away from him. AT: "has caused me to become weak" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: taken away my strength

contextId.information: David is asking God to not let him die. AT: "do not take me away from the earth" (UDB) or "do not let me die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: do not take me away

contextId.information: This means that Yahweh keeps him alive. AT: "He saves me from dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He redeems your life from destruction

contextId.information: This means that God causes it to rain. The waters are described as residing in chambers in the sky. AT: "He waters the mountains by causing the rains to fall from the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He waters the mountains from his water chambers in the sky

contextId.information: Here David describes the amount of things that Yahweh had created as if they were a liquid overflowing out of a container. AT: "is filled with your work!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: overflows with your works

contextId.information: He is comparing his thoughts to something that tastes sweet. AT: "my thoughts be pleasing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my thoughts be sweet

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the increase of Israel as if they were a plant that produced a lot of fruit. "God increased the number of his people greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh made his people fruitful

contextId.information: Here the psalmist describes Yahweh placing a cloud in the sky as if he were spreading out a garment. The cloud was a "covering" to protect them from the sun. AT: "He placed a cloud in the sky to protect them from the sun and heat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He spread a cloud for a covering

contextId.information: The psalmist is asking God to show that he is exalted. Being exalted above the heavens represents being great. AT: "God, show that you are exalted above the heavens" or "God, show that you are great in the heavens" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Be exalted, God, above the heavens

contextId.information: Here David describes God speaking something because he is holy as speaking "in his holiness," as if his holiness were something that he was physically inside of. AT: "God, because he is holy, has said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God has spoken in his holiness

contextId.information: God chose men from the tribe of Judah to be the kings of his people, and he speaks of that tribe as if it were his scepter.  AT: "The tribe of Judah is like my scepter" or "Judah is the tribe through whom I rule my people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Judah is my scepter

contextId.information: God speaks of Moab being unimportant as if Moab were a washbasin or a lowly servant. AT: "Moab is like a bowl that I use for washing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Moab is my washbasin

contextId.information: Here David speaks about Yahweh thinking about their guilt as if their guilt is something physically present before him. AT: "May Yahweh continually think about their sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: May their guilt always be before Yahweh

contextId.information: David speaks of the wicked person's behavior as if it were his clothing. AT: "He cursed other people as often as he wore clothing" or "He cursed people all the time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He clothed himself with cursing as his garment

contextId.information: David feels like he is going to die soon and describes this feeling by comparing himself to a fading shadow and to how the wind blows away locust. AT: "I feel like I am about to die, like an evening shadow that will soon disappear, like a locust is easily blown away by the wind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am fading away like the shadow ... like a locust

contextId.information: David is telling the king that he will have youthful strength each morning by comparing it to how the dew appears early each morning. AT: "each morning you will be filled with youthful strength to sustain you just like each morning the dew appears to water and sustain the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from the womb of the dawn your youth will be to you like the dew

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God blessing the godly person in difficult times as if it were a light shining in darkness. AT: "The blessings that a godly person receives from God are like a light that shines in the darkness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Light shines in the darkness for the godly person

contextId.information: The writer speaks of having peace and confidence as if it were a place where his soul can rest. The word "soul" represents the person. AT: "I can rest in peace again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: My soul can return to its resting place

contextId.information: God is spoken of as if he were a shelter, a place where people can be protected. AT: "to seek protection from Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to take shelter in Yahweh

contextId.information: This verse is parallel to the one preceding it. God is spoken of as if he were a refuge, a place where people can be protected. AT: "to seek protection from Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to take refuge in Yahweh

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the enemy armies trying to defeat him as if they were trying to push him down onto the ground. AT: "in order to defeat me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to knock me down

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh blessing his people as if Yahweh were shining a light on them. AT: "he has blessed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he has given us light

contextId.information: How a person behaves is spoken of as "ways" or "paths." AT: "those whose behavior is blameless" or "those whom no one can blame for doing wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those whose ways are blameless

contextId.information: The writer speaks of being established in God's commandments as if no one could physically make him move. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I would be firmly established

contextId.information: "I have put your words in my heart." This is a metaphor that means "I have memorized your word." The heart is pictured as a container that can hold what people think. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have stored up your word in my heart

contextId.information: The author speaks of gaining understanding, knowledge and wisdom as being able to see. AT: Help me to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Open my eyes so that I may see

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the writers speaks of his short life on earth as if he were a foreigner who would not stay long in the land. AT: "I am like a foreigner living a short time in the land" or 2) the writer's ignorance of God's law as if he were a foreigner who did not know the laws of the land. AT: "I am ignorant like a foreigner in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am a foreigner in the land
