contextId.information: The word "path" here refers to a way of behaving. AT: "Keep me from following the path of deceit" or "Prevent me from being deceptive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Turn from me the path of deceit

contextId.information: How a person behaves or acts is spoken as if it were a road or way. AT: "to be faithful to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the way of faithfulness

contextId.information: Holding tightly to them refers to being committed to obeying them. AT: "I hold tightly to your covenant decrees" or "I am committed to obeying your covenant decrees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I cling to your covenant decrees

contextId.information: The writer speaks of being focused or committed to obeying God's commands as if one is running on a path. AT: "I will be committed to obey your commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will run in the path of your commandments

contextId.information: "Guide me according to your commandments" or "Teach me to obey your commandments." God's commandments are compared to a path that a person walks in obedience to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Guide me in the path of your commandments

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that refers to one desiring things that have no eternal value. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Turn my eyes from looking at worthless things

contextId.information: To walk securely is to live one's life securely. AT: "I will live securely in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I will walk securely

contextId.information: In this metaphor, wicked or evil people tried to cause the writer to sin like a hunter seeking to catch an animal with a trap. AT: "My enemies have tried to catch me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The cords of the wicked have ensnared me

contextId.information: God creating a person is spoken of as if God used his hands to shape the person the way someone may shape clay into an object. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your hands have made and fashioned me

contextId.information: People returning in friendship to the writer is spoken of as if they physically turn towards him. AT: "come to me" or "unite with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turn to me

contextId.information: The proud are seeking to capture the writer or cause him to do wrong. This is spoken of as if they were hunters digging holes to trap the writer like an animal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The proud have dug pits for me

contextId.information: Avoiding doing what is evil is spoken of as if it were avoiding walking on paths that are evil. AT: "I have avoided doing what is evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have kept my feet back from every evil path

contextId.information: Continuing to obey God's righteous decrees is spoken of as if the writer has not physically turned away from the righteous decrees. This can be stated in positive form. AT: "I always obey your righteous decrees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: I have not turned aside from your righteous decrees

contextId.information: Wicked people trying to capture and kill the writer is spoken of as if they were hunters setting a trap to catch an animal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The wicked have set a snare for me

contextId.information: The writer always cherishing and obeying God's decrees is spoken of as if the decrees are land or a possession that the writer will inherit. AT: "Your laws will belong to me forever" or "Your covenant decrees are like a heritage I will keep forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I claim your covenant decrees as my heritage forever

contextId.information: A person who is not sincere and not fully committed to obeying God is spoken of as if the person has two minds. AT: "who are not completely committed to obeying you" or "who are insincere" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who have a double mind

contextId.information: God protecting the writer is spoken of as if God were the writer's shield. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my shield

contextId.information: A person carefully obeying all of God's instructions is spoken of as if as if the instructions were leading a person and that person follows behind. AT: I carefully obey all of your instructions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I carefully follow all your instructions

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh's words as if those words were fabric that is folded, and of the person who explains Yahweh's words as if they are unfolding that fabric. AT: "The explanation of your words gives light" or "When someone explains your words, they give light" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The unfolding of your words gives light

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards him as if Yahweh's face shone a light on him. AT: "Act favorably towards your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let your face shine on your servant

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of affliction as if it were an object that people could see. AT: "Look at how much I am suffering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Look on my affliction

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of salvation as if it were a physical object. The abstract noun "salvation" can be translated using the verb "save." AT: "You will certainly not save the wicked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Salvation is far from the wicked

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of his lips as if they were a container and his praise a liquid that could be poured out. Here the word "lips" is a synecdoche which represents the whole person. AT: "I desire to praise you much" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: May my lips pour out praise

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God severely punishing liars as if God were shooting them with arrows. AT: "He will punish you severely, as if he were shooting you with warrior's arrows" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will punish you with the arrows of a warrior

contextId.information: This metaphor describes how the Israelites could have died to how a fierce animal would attack a smaller animal to eat. AT: "killed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: swallowed us up alive

contextId.information: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a flood of water. AT: "Our enemies would have easily defeated us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The water would have swept us away

contextId.information: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a raging river that would have drowned the Israelites. AT: "our enemies would have destroyed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the raging waters would have drowned us

contextId.information: The writer describes his escape from the enemies as if he was a bird that had escaped from the snare of the hunters. AT: "escaped from our enemies as a bird escapes from the trap that hunters have set" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: escaped like a bird out of the snare of the fowlers

contextId.information: Refusing to obey Yahweh is spoken of as turning away from a good path. AT: "leave good and go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turn aside

contextId.information: Laughing is spoken of as if their mouths were a container and their laughter was in it. It can be made clear that this laughter was a response to their joy. AT: "we laughed for joy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: our mouths were filled with laughter

contextId.information: The cuts from a whipping are spoken of as the plow of a plowman. A farmer plowed deep lines into a field. AT: "My enemies have cut me deeply on my back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The plowers plowed on my back

contextId.information: The author's sadness is spoken of as if it were a container. His sadness comes from the bottom of the container. Sadness is often spoken of as being a container that fills from the top to the bottom. AT: "Because I am very sad," (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Out of the depths

contextId.information: The people of Israel are spoken of as if they were a man. AT: "the people of Israel ... their" or "us people of Israel ... our" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Israel ... his sins

contextId.information: Things that are too hard for a person to understand are spoken of as if they are beyond the person or too far away from the person to be able to reach them. AT:  "things that are too hard to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: things that are beyond me

contextId.information: The place God chose for people to worship him is spoken of as if it were a place where he rests or lives eternally. AT: "the place where you stay" or "your tabernacle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your resting place

contextId.information: Integrity is spoken of as if it were clothing.  AT: "May people recognize that your priests have integrity" or "I want people see how your priests always do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: May your priests be clothed with integrity

contextId.information: Making a king's descendant become king in his place is spoken of as placing him on that king's throne. AT "I will cause one of your descendants to rule Israel in your place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will place one of your descendants on your throne

contextId.information: The place God chose for people to worship him is spoken of as if it were a place where he rests or lives eternally. AT: "the place where I stay" or "my tabernacle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my resting place

contextId.information: God speaks of a powerful descendant of David as if he was the powerful horn of an animal. AT: "I will make a descendant of David become king after him" or "I will cause David to have a descendant who will be a powerful king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make a horn to sprout for David

contextId.information: Shame is spoken of as if it was clothing. This shame would result from losing in war. AT: "I will cause his enemies to be ashamed" or "I will cause his enemies to be defeated and ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will clothe his enemies with shame

contextId.information: A storehouse is a place where things are kept for future use. This imagery shows God's power to control the wind. AT: "causing the wind to blow by his power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bringing the wind out of his storehouse

contextId.information: God's gift of the land to the Israelites is spoken of as if it were inheritance from father to son. AT: "He gave us their land to have forever" or "He gave us their land to be ours forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He gave us their land as an inheritance

contextId.information: The sun, moon, and stars are spoken of as if they were kings. AT: "to mark the time of day ... to mark the time of night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: to rule by day ... to rule by night

contextId.information: Here defeat is spoken of as if it were tipping someone over. AT: "defeated Pharaoh" or "defeated the king of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: overthrew Pharaoh

contextId.information: The condition of feeling shame is spoken of as if it were a place that the Israelites had been in. This is a reference to the many times when the Israelites' enemies had defeated them in battle and shamed them. AT: "cared when we were shamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: helped us in our humiliation

contextId.information: Causing people to be victorious and defeat their enemies is spoken of as giving them victory, as if victory were an object that can be given. AT: "has made us victorious over our enemies" or "has made us able to defeat our enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has given us victory over our enemies

contextId.information: Being in danger is spoken of as being in a physical place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the middle of danger

contextId.information: Here "path" stands for one's behavior. "My path and my lying down" together represent everything about the psalmist. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: my path and my lying down

contextId.information: In the ancient near east, the sun was often imagined as if it had wings which enabled it to fly across the sky. AT: "If the sun could carry me with itself across the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If I fly away on the wings of the morning

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of the night as if it were a blanket that could conceal him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If I said, "Surely the darkness will cover me

contextId.information: This is probably a way of speaking about a mother's womb (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the depths of the earth

contextId.information: Here "way" stands for behavior. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: any wicked way

contextId.information: People who cause conflict by what they say are spoken of as if they had tongues of serpents. Of course, snakes do not do damage with their tongues, but with their bites and especially with poison. Neither can a person make his tongue sharp. Instead, here the idea of a sharp tongue stands for speaking in a way to cause trouble. And the idea the snakes have sharp tongues stands for the fact that many of them have poison. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Their tongues wound like serpents

contextId.information: That is, the power of the wicked (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the hands of the wicked

contextId.information: The exact kinds of traps are less important than the idea that the "wicked ... violent men" are planning to make trouble for the psalmist. If your readers do not know much about trapping, you may need to reduce this down to one line, as the UDB reduces two lines of ULB to one in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:140:001|140:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: set a trap ... spread a net ... set a snare

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks as if giving a rebuke were physically hitting someone. AT: "rebuke me" (UDB) or "hit me so I will listen when he corrects me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hit me

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of deceiving a good man so the good man will sin or so that the evil people can defeat him as if it were laying a trap for an animal. The word "snares" is a metonym for the people themselves. AT: "people who are looking for ways to harm me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the snares that they have laid for me

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of the way people live as if it were a path on which they walk. AT: "how you want me to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the way where I should walk

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "help me to live righteously" or 2) "may my life be free of trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lead me in the land of uprightness

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "the one who keeps me safe" or 2) "the one who gives me strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my rock

contextId.information: The psalmist uses many metaphors to emphasize that Yahweh will protect him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my fortress ... take refuge

contextId.information: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a shield that protects a soldier. Yahweh is the one who protects David from harm. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:002|18:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my shield

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) David speaks of the custom of raising the right hand to swear that what one is about to say in court is true, "they lie even when they swear to tell the truth," or 2) the "right hand" is a metaphor for power, "everything they have gotten, they have gotten by telling lies." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their right hand is falsehood

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) David speaks of the custom of raising the right hand to swear that what one is about to say in court is true, "they lie even when they swear to tell the truth," or 2) the "right hand" is a metaphor for power, "everything they have gotten, they have gotten by telling lies."Translate these words as you translated them in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:144:007|144:7-8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their right hand is falsehood

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh encouraging people as if he were helping people who were physically weak. You may need to translate both lines using only one line. AT "encourages those who are discouraged" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: supports all who are falling ... raises up all those who are bent over

contextId.information: "acts quickly to help those who pray" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is near to all those who call to him

contextId.information: Causing a blind person to see is spoken of as if Yahweh were opening the person's eyes. AT: "causes the blind to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: opens the eyes of the blind

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh honoring those who are oppressed as if Yahweh were lifting them up from the ground. AT: "Yahweh honors the oppressed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh lifts up the oppressed

contextId.information: The writer speaks of strength as if it were the horn of an animal. Lifting up an animal horn was a symbolic action that represented military victory. AT: "He has made his people strong" or "He has given his people victory" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: He has lifted up the horn of his people

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh loving his people as if his people were physically close to him. AT: "the people he loves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the people near to him
